sn9.14:2.3: This is, of course, poetry. In the Vinaya, to be theft it must be something someone owns, and they must perceive it as taken and lost to them.
sn9.14:3.3: Kena vaṇṇena is used occasionally in this idiom (SN 10.2:3.1, Thig 13.4:2.3), which is apparently not attested in Sanskrit. The commentary explains vaṇṇa here as “reason” (kāraṇa). In each context, there is an apparently hidden circumstance that needs to be brought to light. I think it anticipates vaṇṇanā in the sense of “commentary”, “explanation”; cf. English “gloss”.
sn9.14:8.1: The deity disavows dependence on humans and any mutual obligation that may entail. They gave advice freely.
